Award.AwardTitle: CSR: Small: Collaborative Research: Application-Aware Many-Core Virtualization for Real-Time Embedded Computing

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Continued advancements in semiconductor technology make it possible to integrate hundreds of processing cores into one silicon die. However, as the transistor size continues to shrink, increasing manufacturing defects have resulted in severe yield loss and made chip products? profit to drop substantially. Process variations also cause the performance and power characteristics differ significantly from chip to chip. In addition, this non-determinism greatly exacerbates the complexity of developing, validating, and maintaining software built upon these chips, especially for mission-critical real-time embedded applications.

This project explores the hypothesis that architectural virtualization is an effective strategy and will be the norm to address extensive process variations and manufacturing defect problems on many-core platforms. This collaborative research effort seeks to develop effective methods and techniques to virtualize hardware resources on many-core platform and thus isolate the underlying hardware non-determinisms without changing the operating system and application software.

This project seeks to improve the robustness and reliability of software and systems developed on many-core platforms. Techniques developed in the research may also help to address the component upgrade and obsolescence issue, which has been challenging military and avionics industry for decades. The collaborations between PIs and their international collaborators provide a unique opportunity to build an international research and educational collaboration structure, to share research expertise, to enhance the educational opportunity, and to promote cultural exchange. In addition, this project provides opportunity to nurture, encourage and attract students from under-represented groups to engage in this exciting research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As many-core architecture is increasingly being used to supportreal-time and embedded applications, and also as more cores areintegrated in a single chip, it has become an urgent need to developtechniques to tolerate core wear-out failures and improve chipyield. Through this project, we have developed a set of effectivemethods and techniques to maintain the deployed real-timeapplication's timing properties in the presences of core failures andhence eliminate or minimize the impact of the underlying hardwarenondeterministic changes on the applications deployed on the hardware.

We have addressed the problem by classifying the real-time applicationsinto two categories (1) computing intensive applications and (2)communication intensive applications. For computingintensiveapplications, we have developed a Hungarian algorithm basedvirtualization approach to reconfigure a manycore platform and form aunified application specific virtual core topology of which the timingvariations caused by such reconfiguration are minimized. Forcommunication intensive applications, we have developed mixedbinary quadratic programming and greedy algorithms to maintainreal-time application's timing properties before and after manycoreplatform reconfiguration.

In addition to maintain applications' timing properties in thepresences of core wear-outs/failures, to improve system'senergy-efficientand reliability, we also have developed energy-savingtechniques for real-time systems with stringent reliabilityconstraints. For systems with tasks that are of the same criticality,two task execution strategies, i.e. checkpointing based and taskre-execution based strategies are developed to minimize system energyconsumption and at the same time satisfy task deadline and systemreliability constraints.  We have also developed a heuristic searchbased energy minimization strategy for real-time systems withdifferent criticality task sets.  These developed approaches andtechniques are validated through extensive simulations and proved tobe effective.

These developed methodology and technology greatly can reduce thedevelopment and maintenance cost of software, especially those formission-critical real-time embedded applications, and also improve thereliability and performance of such systems. Moreover, through thisproject, new course materials have been integrated intograduate/undergraduate courses, one female graduate student and twofemale undergraduates were able to participate in the front endresearch activities.  Under this project, total twelve (12) journaland fifteen (15) conference peer-reviewed  papers are published.  A set of selected publications are listed below:

Representative Peer-Reviewed Journal Publications:

(1) ``Best-Harmonically-Fit Periodic Task Assignment Algorithm    on Multiple Periodic Resources'', Chunhui Guo, Xiayu Hua, Hao Wu,  Douglas Lautner, and Shangping Ren, IEEE Transactions on Parallel  and Distributed Systems, 2015 (accepted)

(2) ``Energy Minimization for Reliability Guaranteed Real-Time Systems  Using Checkpointing and DVFS Techniques'', Zheng Li and Shangping Ren,  Journal of Software Architecture, Volume 61, No. 2, Jan., 2015. 

(3) ``Maintaining Real-Time Application Timing Similarity For    Defect-Tolerant Network-on-Chip'', Zheng Li, Frank Lockom and  Shangping Ren, ACM Transactions on Embedded Computing System, Volume  13, No. 2, Jan. 2014.

(4) ``Reliability Guaranteed Energy-Aware Frame-Based Task Set    Execution Strategy for Hard Real-Time Systems'', Zheng Li, Li Wang,  Shuhui Li, and Shangping Ren, Journal of System and Software Volume  86, Issue 12, December 2013

(5) ``Quantifying Similarity between Timing Constraint Sets in    Real-Time Systems'', Yue Yu, Shangping Ren and Xiaobo Sharon Hu, ...
